GuideTitle: Take Care of Your PICC Line

substeps.title: Check your line
substeps.description:
• Confirm the green clamps on the extension tubing are open.
• Gently flush with saline (NaCl) — it should go in easily.
• If it's difficult or blocked, do not force it.
substeps.moreInfo: Forcing a blocked line can damage it or cause complications. Contact your care team if flushing is not smooth.

substeps.title: Check for blood return
substeps.description:
• Try to gently pull back with a syringe to check for blood return.
• If there's no return, flush with 20ml saline before and after your antibiotics unless told otherwise.
substeps.moreInfo: Not getting blood return can be normal — your nurse will assess the line regularly.

substeps.title: Inspect the skin
substeps.description:
• Look at and gently feel the skin around your PICC line.
• Watch for redness, swelling, pain, heat, or discharge.
Contact your nurse or clinic immediately if you notice any of these signs.
substeps.moreInfo: These could be early signs of infection or irritation.

substeps.title: Keep it secure
substeps.description: Ensure your line is secured and tucked — avoid pulling or kinking.

steps.title: Keeping Your Line Dry and Safe

substeps.title: Cover your line when you shower
substeps.description:
• Always cover your PICC line with plastic or a waterproof sleeve.
• Avoid getting the dressing wet.
substeps.moreInfo: If the dressing becomes even slightly wet or loose, it must be changed as soon as possible to reduce infection risk.

substeps.title: Avoid soaking and heat
substeps.description: • Do NOT take baths, swim, or use saunas while you have a PICC line.
substeps.moreInfo: Bathing and saunas can expose the line to water, steam, and sweat — all of which increase the chance of infection.

substeps.title: Dressing changes
substeps.description: Your PICC-line will be checked and re-dressed at least once per week, or sooner if the dressing becomes wet or loose.
substeps.moreInfo: Never try to change the dressing on your own — it must be done by trained staff using sterile technique.

substeps.title: Bring used syringes
substeps.description: Place any used syringes with visible blood in a plastic bag and bring them to your next appointment.
substeps.moreInfo: Staff may need to inspect or dispose of them safely, depending on local guidelines.
